message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the principles of rocket propulsion. Igniting the shuttle's boosters causes it to accelerate. The force of the ignited booster engines propels the shuttle forward and increases its velocity. Option (A) is incorrect because when the boosters are ignited properly, the shuttle does not explode. Option (B) is incorrect because the boosters provide thrust and keep the shuttle moving, so it does not stop midair. Option (D) is incorrect because the purpose of igniting the boosters is to increase speed, not slow down or decelerate.

This question requires basic knowledge about the principles of rocket propulsion. Igniting the shuttle's boosters causes it to accelerate. When the boosters are ignited, they generate thrust that propels the shuttle forward. Option (A) is incorrect because ignition does not cause the shuttle to explode. Option (B) is incorrect because if the boosters were to stop midair, the shuttle would not be able to continue its ascent. Option (D) is incorrect because ignition does not cause the shuttle to decelerate.

This question requires basic knowledge about the principles of rocket propulsion. When the boosters of a shuttle are ignited, they generate a large amount of thrust, which causes the shuttle to accelerate and move forward. Option (A) is incorrect because the boosters are designed to explode in a controlled manner to generate thrust, not to create an uncontrolled explosion. Option (B) is incorrect because if the boosters stopped midair, the shuttle would not be able to continue its ascent into space. Option (D) is incorrect because the boosters provide the initial acceleration needed to overcome Earth's gravity, so they do not decelerate the shuttle.

This question requires basic knowledge about propulsion systems and the laws of motion. When the boosters of a shuttle are ignited, it causes the shuttle to accelerate. This is because the force generated by the boosters propels the shuttle forward, increasing its velocity. Option (A) is incorrect because igniting the boosters should not cause the shuttle to explode unless there is a malfunction. Option (B) is incorrect because if the boosters are working properly, they will propel the shuttle forward, not cause it to stop midair. Option (D) is incorrect because deceleration would mean the shuttle is slowing down, which is not the effect of igniting the boosters.

This question requires some basic knowledge about how rockets work. When the boosters of a space shuttle are ignited, it causes the shuttle to accelerate. This is because the force of the ignited boosters propels the shuttle forward, increasing its speed. Option (A) is incorrect because igniting the boosters does not cause the shuttle to explode, although explosive fuels are used for propulsion. Option (B) is incorrect because stopping midair would require a counterforce, which is not provided by igniting the boosters. Option (D) is incorrect because deceleration would require a force opposite to the direction of motion, which is not provided by igniting the boosters.

Option (A) is incorrect because igniting the boosters should not cause the shuttle to explode. Option (B) is incorrect because stopping midair would require some external force or mechanism, not just igniting the boosters. Option (D) is incorrect because deceleration would occur when the boosters are shut off or when the main engines are used to slow down the shuttle.

Option (D) is also incorrect, as deceleration requires a force that opposes the motion, which is not present when the boosters are ignited.
